facts_entailed: Kerosene is refined oil belonging to the hydrocarbon group of compounds, obtained from crude petroleum.

Poisoning is due to inhalation of fumes or ingestion of small amounts accidentally (children) or most cases reported in the literature were self-inflicted with the intention of committing suicide, which constitutes significant emergency admissions.

A 34-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with a history of injecting about 5 ml of kerosene to his left hand at two sites following an argument with family members 2 days prior to presentation, with an intention to commit suicide.
After 2 days, the pain became intolerable, leading to disturbed sleep, with multiple blisters and swelling of the left hand.
No other significant medical history was provided.

 the international continence society 's standardized nomenclature defines mixed urinary incontinence as " the complaint of involuntary leakage associated with urgency and also with exertion , effort , sneezing or coughing . " . the most appropriate definition for mixed incontinence is not known . from a pragmatic standpoint , patients with mui and their clinicians want information about the chance of a favorable outcome following their primary incontinence treatment . 
 the clinical consequences of not understanding the role of the stress and urge components
facts_entailed: Mixed urinary incontinence (mui) is a troublesome condition for patients and incontinence specialists.
Treatment for mixed urinary incontinence requires both the stress and urge components to respond to therapy.

The International Continence Society's standardized nomenclature defines mixed urinary incontinence as 'the complaint of involuntary leakage associated with urgency and also with exertion, effort, sneezing or coughing.'
It is not known which definition is the most appropriate for mixed incontinence.
Patients with mixed incontinence and their clinicians want information about the chance of a favorable outcome following their primary incontinence treatment.
Not understanding the role of the stress and urge components can have clinical consequences.

service user involvement ( sui ) is emphasized in many strategies , plans , and declarations . 
 it is a recognized value in social work and in health care , yet in practice , sui is not always achieved [ 13 ] . 
 there is a dissonance between the philosophies of sui and the existence of these philosophies in the reality of mental health nursing practice . 
 sui is a difficult and complex concept to define , and it is often used as a synonym for participation . on the other hand , a distinction can be made between these two concepts . 
 service user involvement entails preconditions of the service user 's impact on services in some way while user participation can mean users merely taking part in an activity or acting as an informant .

SUI is often used as a synonym for participation.

facts_entailed: A 54-year-old man presented with symptoms including multiple, small, well-defined, gray-brown papules and small papillomatous patches on his penis that appeared over the last year.
Genital warts, lichen planus, a verrucous nevus, and BP were suspected in the clinical diagnosis.
Dermoscopy revealed a pigmented papillomatous surface, brown-gray dots arranged in a linear distribution at the periphery of the lesion, and widespread dotted vessels.
A biopsy was performed, and histology showed mild hyperkeratosis, irregular acanthosis, dyskeratosis, cytological atypia, and mitosis.
The histological findings were consistent with the diagnosis of BP.

peripheral artery disease ( pad ) is a highly prevalent medical condition ,   and it is associated with high prevalence of coexisting vascular diseases in the coronary , cerebral , and renal arteries [ 2 , 3 ] . 
 many patients with pad are physically limited by ambulatory leg pain [ 7 , 8 ] , resulting in baseline ambulatory and physical dysfunction [ 9 , 10 ] , low physical activity [ 11 , 12 ] , and poor health - related quality of life . 
 although pad is considered by many to be a benign disease , as 70 to 80% of patients have stable claudication that does not progress to worsening claudication or critical limb ischemia , pad patients have increased rates of functional decline and mobility loss compared to those without pad , leading to higher rates of hospitalization and loss of inde
facts_entailed: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a highly prevalent medical condition.
PAD is associated with high prevalence of coexisting vascular diseases in the coronary, cerebral, and renal arteries.
Many patients with PAD are physically limited by ambulatory leg pain.
PAD patients experience baseline ambulatory and physical dysfunction.
PAD patients have reduced physical activity.
PAD patients have poorer health-related quality of life.
Although PAD is considered benign by many, it is linked to increased rates of functional decline and mobility loss.
Pad patients have higher rates of hospitalization and loss of independence.

alzheimer 's disease ( ad ) is a degenerative disorder of the human central nervous system ( cns ) . 
 its clinical and neuropathological features are defined by a progressive loss of cognitive function and by the onset of a slowly progressive impairment of memory during mid- to late - adult life . 
 the neuropathological hallmarks of ad include the accumulation and aggregation of amyloid- peptide ( a ) , neurofibrillary tangles , astrocytic gliosis , and reductions in the numbers of both neurons and synapses in many areas of the brain , particularly in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus . strong evidence from multiple studies suggests that defects in a regulation are one of the central biochemical events leading to the development of ad . 
 the neurotoxic a fragment originates from the a
facts_entailed: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a degenerative disorder of the human central nervous system (CNS).
Clinical and neuropathological features of AD include a progressive loss of cognitive function and the onset of a slowly progressive impairment of memory during mid- to late-adult life.

Neuropathological hallmarks of AD include the accumulation and aggregation of amyloid-peptide (A), neurofibrillary tangles, astrocytic gliosis, and reductions in the numbers of both neurons and synapses in many areas of the brain, particularly in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus.
Strong evidence from multiple studies suggests that defects in the regulation are one of the central biochemical events leading to the development of AD.
The neurotoxic A fragment originates from the A.

megaloblastic anemia is an important morbidity in children and adolescents especially in developing countries and with poor socioeconomic status . 
 imerslund grasbeck syndrome ( igs ) is a rare autosomal recessive megaloblastic anemia characterized by selective vitamin ( vit ) b12 deficiency and asymptomatic proteinuria . 
 it is the most common cause of cobalamin deficiency in certain communities like lapps in scandinavia , north african jews , few families in norway and finland . 
 about 300 cases have been reported worldwide with new cases appearing in eastern mediterranean countries . 
 it has varying manifestations like failure to thrive , insidious onset of infections , hematological and neurological symptoms . 
 igs is resistant for oral vit b12 supplements , but responds very well
facts_entailed: Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is a rare autosomal recessive megaloblastic anemia characterized by selective vitamin (vit) B12 deficiency and asymptomatic proteinuria.
It is the most common cause of cobalamin deficiency in certain communities like Lapps in Scandinavia, North African Jews, few families in Norway and Finland.
About 300 cases have been reported worldwide with new cases appearing in eastern Mediterranean countries.
IGS has varying manifestations like failure to thrive, insidious onset of infections, hematological and neurological symptoms.
IGS is resistant to oral vit B12 supplements but responds very well.

facts_entailed: The interplay and architecture of genetic, epigenetic, and environment-induced changes in DNA sequences contribute to large phenotypic variations.

In the post-human genome era, several major international projects including the Human Genome Project, Genome Wide Association Studies, Human Encode Consortium, Dbsnps, Dbcnvs, and HapMap have significantly contributed to understanding DNA and its contributions to phenotypes and diseases.
Variations in anatomical, physiological, immunological, psychological, disease susceptibility, disease prognosis, and response to treatment form the basic principles of personalized medicine.

the pathophysiology of irritable bowel syndrome ( ibs ) seems to involve disturbances at many levels of the so - called gut - brain axis.1 recent research has emphasized the role of food in abdominal symptom generation,2 in particular low - digestible carbohydrates.3 our group has previously shown that the ingestion of the unabsorbable , but fermentable disaccharide lactulose provokes more symptoms in patients with ibs than in healthy individuals.4,5 intriguingly , the symptoms provoked by lactulose were similar to the patients habitual complaints.4 fermentable carbohydrates that escape digestion and absorption within the small intestine are metabolized by colonic microbiota . 
 hunter6 has previously suggested that the disturbances of colonic fermentation play a significant role in ibs sy
facts_entailed: The pathophysiology of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) involves disturbances at many levels of the gut-brain axis.
Recent research has emphasized the role of food in abdominal symptom generation, particularly low-digestible carbohydrates.
Our group has previously shown that the ingestion of the unabsorbable, but fermentable disaccharide lactulose provokes more symptoms in patients with IBS than in healthy individuals.
The symptoms provoked by lactulose were similar to the patients' habitual complaints.
Fermentable carbohydrates that escape digestion and absorption within the small intestine are metabolized by colonic microbiota.
Hunter previously suggested that disturbances of colonic fermentation play a significant role in IBS symptoms.

benign prostatic hyperplasia ( bph ) is one of the most frequently occurring urologic diseases in men older than 50 . 
 the bladder outlet obstruction causes a variety of urinary symptoms including nocturia , incomplete voiding , urgency , and hesitancy and comes to the fore as a significant health problem interrupting the quality of life of men over middle age . 
 the prevalence rate of bph increases with age ; bph occurs in 40% to 70% of men aged 60 to 70 years .

facts_entailed: The prevalence rate of bph increases with age; bph occurs in 40% to 70% of men aged 60 to 70 years.

chronic prostatitis / chronic pelvic pain syndrome ( cp / cpps ) is a common male chronic pain condition . 
 its prevalence ranges from 9 to 16% worldwide and from 5 to 25% in korea [ 1 - 3 ] . 
 cp / cpps presents with various voiding symptoms , perineal or suprapubic pain , erectile dysfunction or sexual disturbance , and psychological problems such as depression and anxiety that have a negative impact on health - related quality of life . 
 various theories have been hypothesized , such as inflammation , pathogen and host - specific factors , pelvic floor tension myalgia , and differences in systemic pressure sensitivity [ 6 - 8 ] . 
 it has been suggested that there are significant psychological components to this condition , because most cp / cpps patients have depression and anxiety
facts_entailed: CP / CPPS presents with various voiding symptoms, perineal or suprapubic pain, erectile dysfunction or sexual disturbance, and psychological problems such as depression and anxiety.
Various theories have been hypothesized, such as inflammation, pathogen and host-specific factors, pelvic floor tension myalgia, and differences in systemic pressure sensitivity.
It has been suggested that there are significant psychological components to this condition, because most CP / CPPS patients have depression and anxiety.

serotonin syndrome is a potentially life - threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity in the central nervous system . 
 it is characterized by mental status changes ( eg , confusion , agitation , lethargy , coma ) , autonomic instability ( eg , hyperthermia , tachycardia , diaphoresis , nausea , vomiting , diarrhea , dilated pupils ) , and neuromuscular hyperactivity ( eg , myoclonus , hyperreflexia , rigidity , trismus ) . 
 serotonin syndrome classically occurs in patients receiving two or more serotonergic drugs , but it can occur with monotherapy . 
 we report a case of a 20-year - old man who developed serotonin syndrome resulting from overdose of escitolapram with concomitant use of cocaine . 
 it is a very important area in medicine as serotonin syndrome should
facts_entailed: It is characterized by mental status changes (eg, confusion, agitation, lethargy, coma), autonomic instability (eg, hyperthermia, tachycardia, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dilated pupils), and neuromuscular hyperactivity (eg, myoclonus, hyperreflexia, rigidity, trismus).
A case of a 20-year-old man developing serotonin syndrome was reported due to an overdose of escitalopram with concomitant use of cocaine.
This topic is considered very important in medicine as serotonin syndrome should be recognized and managed appropriately.

 fallon experienced a cluster of childhood leukemia beginning in 1997 , with the last case announced in 2004 . 
 although the cluster is thought to have abated , at least one additional case of childhood leukemia has occurred in fallon since 2004 . given fallon 's pediatric population of about 2500 children up to 19 years in age , and a national expected rate of childhood leukemia of 4.1 cases per 100,000 children up to 19 years in age per year , the expected rate of childhood leukemia for fallon should be only one case every ten years .

facts_entailed: Size and geography of airborne tungsten particles collected in Fallon, Nevada, and Sweet Home, Oregon (Figure 1) were compared as part of ongoing research on the co-occurrence of airborne tungsten and a cluster of childhood leukemia in Fallon.
A cluster of childhood leukemia began in Fallon in 1997 and was last announced in 2004.
Although the cluster is thought to have abated, at least one additional case of childhood leukemia has occurred in Fallon since 2004.
Fallon has a pediatric population of approximately 2500 children up to 19 years in age.
The national expected rate of childhood leukemia is 4.1 cases per 100,000 children up to 19 years in age per year.
The expected rate of childhood leukemia for Fallon should be one case every ten years.

facts_entailed: A 22-year-old female presented to the hospital with acute abdomen, amenorrhea for a half month and a half, and spotting on and off.
Physical examination revealed normal vital signs for the patient.
Therefore, a serum β-hCG test was performed.

the global prevalence of colorectal cancer is increasing , and the incidence in south korea is rapidly increasing owing to a westernized diet . 
 colon carcinogenesis occurs through either the adenoma - carcinoma sequence or a de novo pathway . 
 it is known that over two - thirds of colorectal cancer cases develop from adenomas ; therefore , detection and removal of adenomas by colonoscopy is the best way to prevent colorectal cancer . according to an american study in 2008 , 
 polyps over 9 mm in size have been detected in 6% to 7% of health screening examinations ; the reported adenoma detection rate in korea varies , but is approximately 9% during screening examinations . diagnosis and removal of colorectal polyps is increasing because of the widespread availability of colonoscopy .
facts_entailed: The global prevalence of colorectal cancer is increasing.
The incidence in South Korea is rapidly increasing owing to a westernized diet.
Colon carcinogenesis occurs through either the adenoma-carcinoma sequence or a de novo pathway.
Over two-thirds of colorectal cancer cases develop from adenomas.
Detection and removal of adenomas by colonoscopy is the best way to prevent colorectal cancer.
According to an American study in 2008, polyps over 9 mm in size have been detected in 6% to 7% of health screening examinations.
The adenoma detection rate in Korea varies during screening examinations, but is approximately 9%.
Diagnosis and removal of colorectal polyps are increasing due to the widespread availability of colonoscopy.

 the algorithm was originally developed as a binary  composite  map and was then improved as positive continuous values .

facts_entailed: Evaluation of radiation dose distribution is essential in radiation therapy.
The gamma function is the most popular algorithm used to evaluate two-dimensional dose distributions.
The gamma function was originally developed as a binary composite map and later improved to use positive continuous values.
Two criteria, dose difference (d) and distance to agreement (dta), are defined to evaluate low- and high-dose gradient regions.
The gamma response, or gamma index, is a positive value.

ethics is defined as the entirety of moral principles that form the basis of individuals behavior ; it can also be defined as  moral theory  or  theoretical ethics  . in a narrower sense , it is the science of  correct  and  incorrect  behaviors . 
 ethics is the philosophy of investigating , through analytical thinking , the values at the basis of relations between humans and the characteristics of the moral terms of good / bad and right / wrong . 
 this characteristic of analytical thinking distinguishes ethics from morals : ethics refers to a system of thought , while moral refers to the set of values that develop on their own with the rise and fall of different societies ( 1 ) . 
 ethics guides how people view the relevance of each decision made in the field of health , and is separate
facts_entailed: Ethics involves the philosophy of investigating, through analytical thinking, the values at the basis of relations between humans and the characteristics of the moral terms of good/bad and right/wrong.
Ethics refers to a system of thought, while morals refer to the set of values that develop on their own with the rise and fall of different societies.
Ethics guides how people view the relevance of each decision made in the field of health, and is separate from morals.

working memory ( wm ) dysfunctions can be found among the difficulties that appear in the functioning of the memory of patients with alzheimer disease ( ad ) . 
 although there are several models of wm , the model proposed by baddeley and hitch [ 2 , 3 ] is one of the most used in the neuropsychological research of cognitive aging . according to this model , the wm system includes 4 components : the phonological loop , which holds verbal information ; the visuospatial sketchpad , which holds visual and spatial information ; an episodic buffer that links the two prior components with long - term memory , and a central executive in charge of the attentional control of information . 
 the verbal component of wm has been one of the most studied in ad patients . in huntley and howard 's   revie
facts_entailed: Several models of working memory exist, but the model proposed by Baddeley and Hitch [2, 3] is commonly used in neuropsychological research of cognitive aging.

According to the Baddeley and Hitch model, the working memory system includes four components: the phonological loop, which holds verbal information; the visuospatial sketchpad, which holds visual and spatial information; an episodic buffer that connects the two prior components with long-term memory; and a central executive responsible for attentional control of information.
The verbal component of working memory has been one of the most studied in patients with Alzheimer disease.

studies on ageing , particularly risk factors that may engender social isolation amongst the elderly population in zambia , are almost nonexistent currently . in fact , very little has been written on ageing in zambia in general . while it is true that some studies have been conducted [ 15 ] by cliggert   none of such studies have based their arguments on possible risk factors likely to foster social isolation among the elderly . 
 further , not only have these studies been devoid of details around the subject itself , but have also tended to be speculative and largely been based on little or no empirical evidence derived from any extensive systematic investigation . in view of this lacuna , therefore , this paper aimed at producing evidence on risk factors likely to engender social isolat
facts_entailed: Some studies have been conducted by Cliggert, but none of them have based their arguments on possible risk factors likely to foster social isolation among the elderly.
These studies have been devoid of details around the subject itself.
These studies have tended to be speculative and largely based on little or no empirical evidence derived from any extensive systematic investigation.
There is a lacuna in the existing research regarding risk factors likely to engender social isolation among the elderly in Zambia.
This paper aims to produce evidence on risk factors likely to engender social isolation among the elderly in Zambia.

facts_entailed: Brain tumours are intracranial neoplasms located in the brain and meninges (excluding haematopoietic malignancies occurring in the brain).
Brain tumours account for approximately 1.4% of all cancers according to references [1, 2].
The incidence of brain and central nervous system tumours worldwide in 2008 was 237,913 new reported cases and is projected to increase to 357,377 by 2030.
Depending on the grade of malignancy, the current standard treatment includes surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy.
One of the challenges in treating brain tumours is the presence of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) that limits the access of systemically administered drugs into the tumour site.
Due to the BBB, lack of lymphatic drainage, and lack of professional antigen presenting cells, effective treatment of brain tumours remains difficult.

accurate and reliable measurements of clinical features of electrocardiogram ( ecg ) signal are most important for effective diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases . in practice , ecg signals are mostly corrupted with different kinds of noise and artefacts such as baseline wander ( bw ) , power - line interference ( pli ) , and muscle artefacts ( ma ) under resting and ambulatory conditions [ 111 ] . 
 the noises present in the ecg signal may mask the morphological features of the local waves such as p - wave , qrs complex , t - wave and u - wave and thus degrade diagnostic quality . 
 various ecg denoising methods were presented based on an adaptive enhancer using second - order statistics , a signal decomposition - based modified bayesian framework , sequential averaging filter using bayes
facts_entailed: The noises present in the ECG signal may mask the morphological features of the local waves such as P-wave, QRS complex, T-wave, and U-wave and thus degrade diagnostic quality.

facts_entailed: The interplay between nutrition and physical activity is frequently misunderstood.
The relationship between industrialization and global climate is also frequently misunderstood.
Most people either underemphasize or overemphasize the importance of nutrition to exercise performance.
In the broader sense, there exists a battle between basic science and applied research.
Our applied research is totally based on the sound fundamentals of the subjects concerned.
Christoph Lichtenberg was a German physicist and philosopher who lived more than 200 years ago at the beginning of 1782.

facts_entailed: Good photochemical properties, chemical stability, and ease of synthesis make coumarins an important class of fluorescent probes for biological studies.
Coumarins can also be used as light-removable protecting groups, known as caging groups.
Caged molecules have been extensively applied in the optical control of cellular processes.
The 6-bromo-7-hydroxycoumarin methyl caging group undergoes fast two-photon photolysis at 740 nm.
The 6-bromo-7-hydroxycoumarin methyl caging group has been used to optically control neurotransmitters, secondary messengers, and oligonucleotides.
Two-photon irradiation enables optical activation of biological processes with enhanced tissue penetration up to 1 mm.
Two-photon caging has been used in the optical control of cellular processes.

facts_entailed: The prevalence in patients under cesarean section (c/s) is 80-90%.
Hypotension causes unpleasant symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, unconsciousness, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest in mothers.
In severe and prolonged conditions, hypotension leads to the impairment of uterine perfusion and ultimately fetal acidosis and neonatal depression.
The required spinal block height for cesarean section (c/s) is at t4-t6 dermatome level.
To avoid expanded sympathetic block and hypotension, the spread of local anesthetic in the subarachnoid space should not be higher than the t4 dermatome level.
The most common local anesthetic for spinal anesthesia in patients under obstetric and non-obstetric surgery is bupivacaine, which can be used as isobaric or hyperbaric solution.

metabolic syndrome is a wellestablished risk factor for cardiovascular disease ( cvd ) , including coronary artery disease and heart failure.1 alterations in metabolic risk linked to cvd may develop over decades before clinical cvd.2 , 3 , 4 , 5 prior work in large , communitybased populations have defined a role for early , cumulative changes in blood pressure6 and obesity7 in forecasting risk of subclinical cvd in midlife and beyond . 
 lifecourse  perspective on cardiometabolic risk  and resulting recommendations to maintain an ideal body weight , diet , physical activity , and lipid profile  is critical to decrease incident cvd.8 although obesity has frequently been cited as a central pathogenic factor for cvd risk , emerging literature suggests that cardiometabolic risk may evolve ind
facts_entailed: Metabolic syndrome is a well-established risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), including coronary artery disease and heart failure.
Alterations in metabolic risk linked to CVD may develop over decades before clinical CVD.
Prior work in large, community-based populations has defined a role for early, cumulative changes in blood pressure and obesity in forecasting risk of subclinical CVD in midlife and beyond.
A lifecourse perspective on cardiometabolic risk and resulting recommendations to maintain an ideal body weight, diet, physical activity, and lipid profile is critical to decrease incident CVD.
Although obesity has frequently been cited as a central pathogenic factor for CVD risk, emerging literature suggests that cardiometabolic risk may evolve independently of obesity.

 control of the subcellular localization of pka and pkc activities in a temporal manner by a - kinase - anchoring proteins ( akap ) has emerged as a pivotal mechanism to control cell migration .

facts_entailed: The actin cytoskeleton plays an essential role in numerous aspects of cell biology such as cell adhesion, cell morphology, cytokinesis, and migration.

Cell migration machinery is regulated by signaling intermediates that can be activated by diverse stimuli and that can exert control over a large number of downstream target molecules, all with temporal and spatial specificity.
Pka, Pkc, and Ca-binding proteins are examples of cellular regulators that mediate diverse effects on cytoskeletal dynamics, cell adhesion, and cell migration.
Control of the subcellular localization of Pka and Pkc activities in a temporal manner by a-kinase-anchoring proteins (Akap) has emerged as a pivotal mechanism to control cell migration.

 for example , dysarthria is an early - onset sign in individuals with parkinson disease typically starting with changes to vocal loudness and quality [ 1 - 6 ] .

facts_entailed: Dysarthria is an early-onset sign in individuals with Parkinson disease, typically starting with changes to vocal loudness and quality.

As the disease progresses, vocal acoustic and auditory-perceptual features degrade and cause reduced amplitude (loudness), decreased variation of intonation (monopitch and monoloudness), and increased signal to noise ratio (breathiness/harshness in vocal quality).

 once it is diagnosed in the oral cavity , the patient must be supervised regularly to control potential systemic complications of the disease . 
 some authors attest that localized form has a better prognosis , in particular when the head and neck area is affected . 
 the subtypes are currently named according to the specific protein that is deposited , using the prefix a for amyloid , followed by letters that indicate the protein .

 a specimen is placed on a rotary stage between the x - ray source and the detector .

facts_entailed: The high resolution x - ray computed tomography (xCT) has gained considerable importance and acceptance for the examination and 3D characterization of materials and industrial specimens in recent years.
Wide use of xCT systems with cone beam geometry, including those with a-focus or nano-focus x-ray tubes and high-speed/high-resolution flat panel matrix detectors, is common in materials science.
A specimen is placed on a rotary stage between the x-ray source and the detector when using cone beam xCT.
The specimen is rotated step by step while taking projection images at each angular position during cone beam xCT scanning.
A computer cluster reconstructs the projections into a volume dataset using algorithms like the filtered back projection method.

soil - transmitted helminths ( sth ) or geohelminths infect more than 2 billion people worldwide , especially in developing countries located in tropical and subtropical regions .

it is clear that while oxygen is essential for life in order to produce chemical energy in the form of atp , paradoxically , the byproduct of its metabolism generates multiple reactive oxygen species ( ros ) that are associated with cellular toxicity . 
 specifically , in regards to neurodegeneration , there is substantial evidence that ros are a major component of diseases including alzheimer 's , parkinson 's , and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis [ 14 ] .

facts_entailed: Paradoxically, the byproduct of oxygen metabolism generates multiple reactive oxygen species (ROS).

Clinical trials aimed at decreasing the burden of oxidative stress have not clearly demonstrated effectiveness.
Animal models have indicated that oxidative stress is an important and consistent characteristic.

Amyloid has a particularly dismal outcome with less than 5% of patients surviving 5 years after diagnosis.
Individuals aged 80 are expected to survive an additional three years.

Advanced age in older adults is often accompanied by frailty and comorbidities.

Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is increasingly being performed.
According to TAVR guidelines, pre-procedural planning requires a contrast-computed tomography (CT) from thorax to iliofemoral vessels.
Due to the higher prevalence of tumors in elderly patients, more potential malignant incidental findings (PMIFS) may be encountered if a radiologic PMIF appears.

The clinical signs were typical of an upper respiratory tract infection combined with severe obstructive bronchitis.
Chest radiographs showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates and total atelectasis of the right upper lung lobe.

yoga is an ancient indian science as well as the way of life , which includes practice of specific posture ( asana ) , regulated breathing ( pranayama ) etc . 
 breath is the dynamic bridge between body and mind and pranayama ( breathing techniques ) is one of the most important yogic practices , which can produce different physiological responses in healthy individuals . 
 pranayama is an art of prolongation and control of breath , which helps to bring the conscious awareness in breathing ; to reshape breathing habits and patterns . 
 the persistent conditioning of breathing pattern of pranayama increases the pulmonary function in healthy individuals .

facts_entailed: The ancient Indian science of yoga encompasses the practice of specific postures (asana) and regulated breathing (pranayama).
Breath acts as a dynamic link between the body and mind.
One of the most important yogic practices is pranayama, which involves controlling and prolonging breath.
Pranayama aims to enhance conscious awareness in breathing and reshape breathing habits and patterns.
The persistent practice of pranayama can increase pulmonary function in healthy individuals.
Various pranayamas exist within yogic practices, but bhramari pranayama and om chanting are used for expiratory exercises.

facts_entailed: High concentrations of factor viii and von willebrand factor (vwf) contribute to a hypercoagulable state in hyperthyroidism.
Lower vwf concentrations in hypothyroidism may protect against venous thrombosis.
A 45-year-old female presented in the emergency with complaints of headache for 1 month, vomiting for 1 day, and weakness with numbness and tingling in the right half of the body for 12 hours.
Her weakness progressed to quadriparesis overnight.
On examination, she was drowsy and disoriented.
On neurological examination, reflexes were present and muscle tone was normal but power was 1/5 on the right side and 3/5 in the left half of the body.

 previous reports have shown that berberine has several pharmacological and biological properties including antibiotic ( mirska et al . , 1972 ) , anti - inflammatory ( marinova et al . , 2000 ; zhou and mineshita , 2000 ; yoo et al . , 2008 ) and anti - hypolipidemic ( kong et al . , 2004 ) effects .

facts_entailed: Berberine is an isoquinoline alkaloid and often isolated from goldenthread, coptidis rhizoma, and goldenseal (Mirska et al., 1972).

Previous reports have shown that berberine has several pharmacological and biological properties including antibiotic (Mirska et al., 1972), anti-inflammatory (Marinova et al., 2000; Zhou and Mineshita, 2000; Yoo et al., 2008), and anti-hypolipidemic (Kong et al., 2004) effects.
Berberine has been reported to attenuate neuronal damage in ischemia/reperfusion model (Yoo et al., 2006) and in autoimmune encephalomyelitis model mice (Ma et al., 2010).
Berberine showed neuroprotective effects on stroke models (Zhou et al., 2008) and focal cerebral ischemia injury (Xiao et al., 2007).

adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare and a highly malignant neoplasm   it grows rapidly and tends to metastasize to the liver and lungs and to invade the kidney , renal veins and the inferior vena cava   dissemination of the tumor occurs in 82% of the patients with a median survival of 14.5 months   cardiac involvement of adrenal carcinoma is very rare ; less than 20 cases have been described [ 4 - 15 ] . 
 the main therapeutic approach is adrenalectomy and extraction of the tumor from the inferior vena cava and the right atrium . 
 this requires a precise evaluation of the extent of spread of the tumor , a meticulous pre - operative planning and a combined team including general and cardiac surgeons and a cardio - pulmonary bypass team . 
 jugular venous pulse and heart sounds were normal .
facts_entailed: adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare and highly malignant neoplasm that grows rapidly and tends to metastasize to the liver and lungs and to invade the kidney, renal veins, and the inferior vena cava.
82% of patients with adrenocortical carcinoma experience tumor dissemination.
The median survival for patients with adrenocortical carcinoma is 14.5 months.
Cardiac involvement of adrenocortical carcinoma is very rare, with less than 20 cases described in literature.
The main therapeutic approach for adrenocortical carcinoma includes adrenalectomy and the extraction of the tumor from the inferior vena cava and the right atrium.

This therapeutic approach requires a precise evaluation of the tumor's extent, meticulous pre-operative planning, and a multidisciplinary team involving general and cardiac surgeons, as well as a cardio-pulmonary bypass team.

facts_entailed: The basic mechanism of action in the freezing of tissue involves the formation of ice crystals.
Ice crystals disrupt cell membranes and organelles.
Cells exposed to freezing temperatures of about 5 to 15°C at the periphery of the ice crystal/ice ball primarily undergo apoptotic cell death.
Necrotic cell death occurs at colder temperatures (<20°C) due to direct damage to cell organelles and membranes.
At the periphery where temperatures are warmer (20 to 0°C), extracellular ice formation causes the environment to become hyperosmotic, thus removing water from the cells.

 other medications such as alpha 1-adrenergic blockers , angiotensin - conver
facts_entailed: Raynaud's syndrome was first described in 1862.
Raynaud's syndrome affects between 3% and 10% of the population without preference for a certain sex or ethnicity.
It is characterized by alterations in peripheral adrenoceptor activity resulting in vasoconstriction and ischemia of the extremities in response to low temperature or emotional stress.
This ischemia can cause pain and necrosis of tissues, ultimately leading to amputation if left untreated.
Traditionally, most patients can be managed with avoidance of cold exposure and emotional stress.
When conservative management is inadequate, a number of pharmacological, surgical, and behavioral therapies have been used.
Among medical interventions, other medications such as alpha 1-adrenergic blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors have been used.

neuromuscular blocking agents ( nmbas ) are routinely used worldwide as part of a modern concept of balanced anesthesia . 
 rocuronium , an aminosteroid nmba , and cisatracurium , a nmba of the benzylisoquinoline family , are two common intermediate - duration nmbas whose pharmacokinetic properties make them suitable for administration by either bolus or continuous infusion.1 rocuronium features a rapid onset of action.2 when a rapid induction of nmb is required , rocuronium 11.2 mg / kg may be substitutive of succinylcholine , which is effective , but has a wide range of potentially dangerous adverse effects , including death.3 cisatracurium has an organ - independent metabolism since it is ( at physiological ph and temperature ) rapidly degraded by hoffmann elimination in plasma and tiss
facts_entailed: Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) are routinely used worldwide as part of a modern concept of balanced anesthesia.
Rocuronium and cisatracurium are two common intermediate-duration NMBAs.
Rocuronium is an aminosteroid NMBA.
Cisatracurium is a NMBA of the benzylisoquinoline family.
Rocuronium features a rapid onset of action.
When a rapid induction of NMB is required, rocuronium 11.2 mg/kg may be substituted for succinylcholine.
Cisatracurium has an organ-independent metabolism.

facts_entailed: There is strong epidemiological support for a role of high salt intake in hypertension.
Controlled interventions modulating salt intake have shown that high salt intake elevates blood pressure.
The degree of blood pressure reduction following a lowering of salt intake varies between individuals.
It is not known what role increased water intake and water retention have for salt-induced blood pressure elevation.
Increased salt intake is likely to lead to elevations in blood pressure.
The two main stimulants of arginine vasopressin (AVP) secretion are hypovolemia and increased osmolarity.

 sof was found to act on a lipoprotein fraction of serum [ 2 , 3 ] and   various enzymatic activities were proposed to account for the opacity reaction of sof including those as a cholesterol esterase   and apolipoproteinase or aspartic protease .   subsequently , sof was found not to be a hydrolase but rather induced opacification of serum by binding to high - density lipoproteins ( hdls ) , displacing apolipoprotein a - i ( apo a - i ) and disrupting the structure of hdl resulting in the formation of large , lipid particles that cause serum to become opaque     [ 6 , 7 ] .

facts_entailed: Serum opacity factor (SOF) was first discovered in 1938 by the Australians Ward and Rudd as a substance produced by Group A Streptococci that caused serum to become cloudy (Figure 1), hence its name.

SOF acts on a lipoprotein fraction of serum [2, 3] and various enzymatic activities were proposed to account for the opacity reaction of SOF including cholesterol esterase and apolipoproteinase or aspartic protease.

Subsequently, SOF was found not to be a hydrolase but rather induced opacification of serum by binding to high-density lipoproteins (HDLs), displacing apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I) and disrupting the structure of HDLs resulting in the formation of large, lipid particles that cause serum to become opaque [6, 7].

recordings of electrical and mechanical activity in vitro from gastrointestinal smooth muscle segments show rhythmic mechanical activity that is triggered by corresponding rhythmic changes in membrane potential.13 the underlying membrane potential changes are usually composed of two events , starting with a slow rhythmic change ( often denoted as slow waves ) , which serves to depolarize the membrane potential to a sufficient level to elicit a second event , which is the spike or action potential ( figure 1 ) . 
 although in some gastrointestinal smooth muscles slow waves themselves may trigger contractions,4 the usual physiologic trigger for contractions is considered the spike . 
 the depolarizing phase of the spike is predominantly a result of an influx of calcium.2,5 considering the na
facts_entailed: The recordings show rhythmic mechanical activity in gastrointestinal smooth muscle segments.
Rhythmic changes in membrane potential trigger this mechanical activity.
The underlying membrane potential changes consist of two events: slow waves and spikes.
Slow waves serve to depolarize the membrane potential.
Spike or action potentials are elicited by the depolarization caused by slow waves.
The spike is the usual physiologic trigger for contractions in gastrointestinal smooth muscles.
Slow waves alone may sometimes trigger contractions in some gastrointestinal smooth muscles.
The depolarizing phase of the spike is primarily due to an influx of calcium.

facts_entailed: The man was part of a group of 148 refugees from the Eastleigh community in Nairobi, Kenya, who arrived in the United States from November 3 through 15.
The sequence of the virus sample was identical to sequences from measles viruses collected in Nairobi and Machakos, Kenya, in October 2005.
All but one of the six viruses collected from Nairobi were from patients in the Eastleigh area of Nairobi, where an outbreak of measles had been reported among Somali and Ethiopian communities.

facts_entailed: The term 'mycotic aneurysm' was first used by Osler in 1885 to describe a mushroom-shaped aneurysm in a patient with subacute bacterial endocarditis.
The term 'infected aneurysm' is more appropriate, since few infections involve fungi.
Mycobacterium and fungi, such as Candida albicans and Aspergillus, are rare causes of infected aneurysms.
Few cases of mycotic abdominal aorta aneurysms have been reported as per the literature search.
Mycotic aortic aneurysm usually manifests as abdominal pain with or without a pulsatile mass, depending on the location.

Myxoid chondrosarcoma is often misdiagnosed as chordoma.

australia is home to a vast array of endemic marsupial species ( superorder australidelphia ) . of an estimated 162 marsupial species present at the time of european settlement in 1788 , twelve species have since become extinct , and many others have suffered major contraction of distribution and substantial to severe population declines ( burbidge et  al . , 2009 , woinarski , 2015 ) .

 the majority of these neoplasms are astrocytic , often high grade , and the diagnosis is usually made postmortem [ 1 , 2 ] .

We report a fourth case.

 bevacizumab , a monoclonal antibody against vascular endothelial growth factor ( vegf ) , has been used most commonly in combination with irinotecan or other cytotoxic agents as salvage therapy .

facts_entailed: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a neoplasm with variable features both histologically and biologically.

GBM is characterized by diverse imaging features, including highly heterogeneous enhancement, reflecting variable disruption of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and inherent differences in the vascularity of the tumor.

facts_entailed: The first step in gene expression is transcription.
Transcription is mediated and regulated by transcription factors (TFS).
TFS bind DNA in a sequence-specific manner on transcription factor binding sites (TFBS), usually located near the transcription start site (TSS) of genes (i.e., in the promoter region).
Transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) are also found in distal elements like enhancers or silencers.
Several studies aimed at characterizing the DNA binding specificity of TFS have been performed.
Earlier studies could identify single binding sites.
Larger-scale genome-wide experiments, such as chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with genome tiling microarrays or next-generation sequencing, have been conducted.
A set of sites experimentally known to be recognized by a given TF can be used to build models.

left ventricular pseudoaneurysm is a rare condition because in most instances ventricular free - wall rupture leads to fatal pericardial tamponade . 
 rupture of the free wall of the left ventricle is a catastrophic complication of myocardial infarction , occurring in approximately 4% of patients with infarcts , resulting in immediate collapse of the patient and electromechanical dissociation . in rare cases 
 the rupture is contained by pericardial and fibrous tissue , and the result is a pseudoaneurysm . 
 the left ventricular pseudoaneurysm contains only pericardial and fibrous elements in its wall - no myocardial tissue . 
 because such aneurysms have a strong tendency to rupture , this disorder may lead to death if it is left surgically untreated . 
 in this case report , we present a
facts_entailed: Left ventricular pseudoaneurysm is a rare condition.
Ventricular free-wall rupture typically leads to fatal pericardial tamponade.
Rupture of the left ventricle's free wall is a catastrophic complication of myocardial infarction in approximately 4% of patients with infarcts.
Immediate collapse and electromechanical dissociation can occur with left ventricle free-wall rupture in myocardial infarction.
In rare cases, the rupture is contained by pericardial and fibrous tissue, leading to a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm.
A left ventricular pseudoaneurysm contains only pericardial and fibrous elements in its wall, with no myocardial tissue.
Such aneurysms have a strong tendency to rupture, potentially leading to death if left untreated.
This case report discusses a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm.

halitosis , or bad breath , is a condition in which the halitus is altered in a manner unpleasant for both the affected individual and those with whom he / she interacts . 
 this phenomenon may be caused by a number of factors and may or may not be a pathological condition.1,2 this condition is also known as fetid halitus , mouth odor , bad breath and bad mouth odor.3,4 the odor may be a significant social and psychological disadvantage for affected individuals.5 halitosis is a common complaint of both genders .

facts_entailed: Halitosis is also known as fetid halitus, mouth odor, bad breath, and bad mouth odor.
Halitosis is a common complaint of both genders.
It occurs worldwide and has a multifactorial etiology.
Its main cause is the decomposition of organic matter caused by proteolytic anaerobic bacteria in the oral cavity.
Halitosis is generally classified as either primary or secondary.

critical limb ischemia ( cli ) mainly affects elderly patients with important comorbidities and significant diffuse multilevel vascular lesions [ 1 , 2 ] . 
 these patients are frequently diabetics with neuroischemic limb ulcers , gangrene , and foot sepsis . 
 this specific group is prone to develop an aggressive form of the disease , with more tibial affectation and microcirculatory impairment [ 3 , 4 ] . 
 the risk of limb loss is higher among diabetics and in patients with ischemic ulcers [ 1 , 2 ] . in the absence of a successful revascularization , 
 major amputation and mortality rates of cli patients are substantial . in this context , obtaining at least one patent tibial artery to the foot is usually needed to achieve a sufficient amount of blood flow to cover the healing process
facts_entailed: The condition critical limb ischemia (CLI) mainly affects elderly patients with important comorbidities and significant diffuse multilevel vascular lesions.
This specific group is prone to develop an aggressive form of the disease, with more tibial affectation and microcirculatory impairment.
The risk of limb loss is higher among diabetics and in patients with ischemic ulcers.
In the absence of successful revascularization, major amputation and mortality rates for CLI patients are substantial.
To achieve a sufficient amount of blood flow to cover the healing process, at least one patent tibial artery to the foot is usually needed.

patients with acute heart failure syndromes ( ahfs ) are usually admitted because of severe systemic congestion that frequently presents with dyspnea . 
 known as the hallmark of ahfs , congestion is mainly due to pulmonary venous hypertension ( world health organization type 2 ) . 
 this has ranged from < 2%   to 7.7%   to 29%   depending on the series . 
 dyspnea is the most common symptom in these patients that implies an elevated pulmonary venous pressure that is often accompanied by increased central venous pressure ( cvp ) and/or peripheral edema .

 moreover , it is well established that patients who are admitted with ahfs and renal dysfunction
facts_entailed: Congestion is characterized as the hallmark of AHFS and is mainly caused by pulmonary venous hypertension (WHO type 2).
The prevalence of congestion ranges from less than 2% to 7.7% to 29% depending on the series.
Dyspnea is the most common symptom in these patients, implying an elevated pulmonary venous pressure which is often accompanied by increased central venous pressure (CVP) and/or peripheral edema.
There is substantial evidence that volume overload is the main driver of morbidity, mortality, and readmission to the hospital for patients with AHFS.
It is well-established that patients with AHFS and renal dysfunction are at higher risk.

In vertebrates, this peptide belongs to a superfamily of structurally related proteins, the insulin-related family of substances, which includes insulin-like growth factors-1 (IGF-1) and -2 (IGF-2) and relaxin.

After the detection of immunoreactive insulin in dog cerebrospinal fluid, the idea that insulin could not cross the blood-brain barrier and affect the central nervous system was challenged.
Further studies provided clear evidence that insulin occurs in the brain, where it may reach high levels.

source: long - term oxygen therapy ( ltot ) is one of the main treatments for patients with stage iv chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( copd ) and is associated with improved survival (  evidence a ,  according to the evidence level scheme employed in previous global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease reports).1 other benefits of treatment include hemodynamic improvement in hematological parameters , increased exercise capacity , improved quality of life , and improved mental state.14 the home conditions for use of a complex treatment such as ltot can be far from ideal.5 the recommendations made when prescribing may not be carried out at home , and treatment noncompliance interferes with the effectiveness of ltot.6 a study by hjalmarsen et al7 showed that patients with hypoxemia
facts_entailed: Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is one of the main treatments for patients with stage IV chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
LTOT is associated with improved survival according to the evidence level scheme.
Other benefits of LTOT include hemodynamic improvement, increased exercise capacity, improved quality of life, and improved mental state.
The conditions for using LTOT at home are often suboptimal.
Recommendations for using LTOT may not be followed at home.
Treatment non-compliance can interfere with the effectiveness of LTOT.
A study by Hjalmarsen et al. demonstrated that patients with hypoxemia had lower levels of oxygen therapy adherence.

complex sphingolipids , including sphingomyelin ( sm ) and glycosphingolipids ( gsls ) , are essential components of intestinal membranes , providing protection and integrity to the mucosa and regulating intestinal digestion and absorption processes . as in other organs , in the intestine , simple sphingolipids / sphingoids , which are intermediates of sphingolipid metabolism , are involved in the control of key cellular events such as survival , proliferation , differentiation , and apoptosis . 
 indeed , the metabolism of complex sphingolipid includes enzymes involved in different signaling pathways , which lead to the formation of bioactive molecules , including ceramide ( cer ) and sphingosine ( sph ) , as well as their 1-phosphorylated derivatives ceramide-1-phosphate ( c1p ) and sphi
facts_entailed: Complex sphingolipids, including sphingomyelin (SM) and glycosphingolipids (GSLs), are essential components of intestinal membranes.
Simple sphingolipids/sphingoids are intermediates of sphingolipid metabolism and involved in controlling key cellular events such as survival, proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis.
The metabolism of complex sphingolipids involves enzymes that lead to the formation of bioactive molecules like ceramide (Cer) and sphingosine (Sph).
Complex sphingolipid metabolism also produces phosphorylated derivatives such as ceramide-1-phosphate (C1P) and sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P).

facts_entailed: Steroid has a main role in treatment for nephrotic syndrome.
Patients who do not respond appropriately to steroid have a greater chance of attaining end stage renal disease (esrd).
Available standard biochemical markers are not sensitive enough to determine high-risk patients.

facts_entailed: Human saliva is a complex secretion containing a mixture of inorganic and organic molecules.
The tooth surface is protected by a film of salivary mucins and proline-rich glycoprotein.

Human saliva contains at least two structurally and functionally distinct populations of secreted mucins: the high molecular weight (Mr>10 kDa) polymeric, gel-forming population (muc5b) and the lower molecular weight (Mr 1.2-15 kDa) non-polymerizing population (muc7).
Secreted salivary mucins, muc5b and muc7, provide lubrication, protect oral tissue surfaces, and modulate oral microorganisms.

In MN, immunofluorescence shows granular staining with immunoglobulin G (IgG) and/or C3.

 relapse frequently occurs within 6 months or less from the initiation of chemotherapy and most patients experience rapid progression that is refractory to conventional chemotherapy .

sporotrichosis is a chronic mycosis that affects skin and subcutaneous tissues , but it also can spread to other organs through the lymph vessels [ 14 ] . 
 it is acquired by traumatic implantation of the etiologic agent , the dimorphic fungus sporothrix schenckii . 
 the mycelial morphotype is found in soil , wood , and plants , while the yeast morphotype is found in host tissues [ 6 , 7 ] . 
 surface components of s. schenckii cell wall ( cw ) have a possible role in its pathogenicity . 
 accordingly , ergosterol peroxide helps the organism to evade the host 's immune response , promoting fungal infection . 
 also , a lipid antigen has been shown to decrease the production of proinflammatory cytokines such as tnf- , il-1 , and also il-12 and il-10 in experimental models of sporotrichosis
facts_entailed: Surface components of S. schenckii cell wall (CW) have a possible role in its pathogenicity.
A lipid antigen has been shown to decrease the production of proinflammatory cytokines such as TNF-, IL-1, and also IL-12 and IL-10 in experimental models of sporotrichosis.

 although mortality is rather variable around the world ( the rates between 20% and 63% ) , 750,000 sepsis cases and 210,000 related deaths are reported annually in the united states during the year 2000 [ 2 , 3 ] . 
 a directory for sepsis diagnosis and treatment , released by the surviving sepsis campaign ( ssc ) [ 4 , 5 ] , points out that early identification and effective intervention will significantly improve prognosis and reduce death rate

facts_entailed: Sepsis is one of the most important causes of morbidity and mortality in the intensive care unit (ICU).

A directory for sepsis diagnosis and treatment, released by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign (SSC), points out that early identification and effective intervention will significantly improve prognosis and reduce death rate.

The composition of cell membranes is complex, with constituent species including, but not limited to, saturated and unsaturated PC and PE lipids, sphingomyelin and cholesterol, which serve as a matrix in which membrane proteins may reside.
Cell membranes possess functions such as regulating transport into and out of the cell and modulating the activity of membrane-embedded ion channels and proteins.

studies have shown that most acute coronary syndromes ( acs ) result from the rupture of unstable plaques and subsequent thrombus formation ( 1 , 2 ) . the risk of atherosclerotic plaque disruption and thrombosis is thought to be closely related to plaque composition rather than the severity of an actual luminal stenosis ( 3 - 5 ) .

facts_entailed: It is of paramount clinical importance to elucidate the composition of coronary atherosclerotic plaques.
Atherosclerotic plaque imaging is performed through arterial wall imaging.
Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease of the vessel wall that frequently occurs in the aorta and carotid, coronary, and peripheral arteries.

t cell development is unique among all hematopoietic lineages ; it  requires a distinct organ , the thymus . 
 thymic epithelial cells ( tecs ) provide unique structural and functional niches , which allow for t  cell lineage induction , somatic generation , and subsequent selection (  quality control  ) of the nascent t  cell repertoire ( anderson and takahama , 2012 ) . 
 the two major subsets of tecs  cortical ( ctecs ) and medullary tecs ( mtecs)define the two structural compartments of the thymus , the cortex and the medulla . 
 t  cells migrate during their development through both compartments in a spatially and temporally ordered process . during the cortical phase , 
 a highly diverse t  cell repertoire is generated in a random fashion and subjected to positive selection for self
facts_entailed: t cell development is unique among all hematopoietic lineages.
It requires a distinct organ, the thymus.
Thymic epithelial cells (TECs) provide unique structural and functional niches.
T cells migrate through both the cortical and medullary compartments during their development.
During the cortical phase, a highly diverse t cell repertoire is generated in a random fashion and subjected to positive selection for self.

in a previous issue of critical care , prowle and colleagues describe the results of a cohort study in which incidence and attributable mortality of bloodstream infection ( bsi ) were investigated in university - affiliated hospitals . 
 the cohort included 6,339 patients with an icu stay > 72 hours , of which 330 developed an icu - acquired bsi . 
 mortality associated with bsi was 41.2% and thereby substantially higher compared to patients without bsi ( 22.5% ) . 
 after adjustment for confounding covariates , bsi remained an independent risk factor for death ( hazard ratio 2.9 , 95% confidence interval 2.4 to 3.5 ) . 
 the study by prowle and colleagues , however , goes beyond impact estimates for patients who are affected by this infectious complication . 
 the investigators linked the
facts_entailed: Mortality associated with BSI was 41.2% compared to 22.5% for patients without BSI.
After adjusting for confounding covariates, BSI remained an independent risk factor for death with a hazard ratio of 2.9.
The study by prowle and colleagues examined more than just the impact on affected patients.

carcinoma of the gallbladder is more common in women and usually seen in patients older than 50 years of age . 
 it is more common in the white population than the black and in western countries than the mediterranean . 
 although areas of squamous differentiation is seen in adenocarcinoma , pure primary squamous cell carcinoma is rarely reported and accounts for less than 1% of all gallbladder malignancies . 
 some researchers have stated that squamous cell carcinoma originates from pre - existing squamous metaplasia of the gallbladder epithelium , while others concluded that it originates from squamous differentiation of neoplastic cells of adenocarcinoma . 
 we present a pure case of squamous cell carcinoma with some areas of squamous metaplasia in the vicinity of the invasive tumor .
facts_entailed: Carcinoma of the gallbladder is more common in women and usually seen in patients older than 50 years of age.
It is more common in the white population than the black and in Western countries than the Mediterranean.
Areas of squamous differentiation are seen in adenocarcinoma.
Pure primary squamous cell carcinoma is rarely reported and accounts for less than 1% of all gallbladder malignancies.
Some researchers state that squamous cell carcinoma originates from pre-existing squamous metaplasia of the gallbladder epithelium.
Others conclude that squamous cell carcinoma originates from squamous differentiation of neoplastic cells of adenocarcinoma.
We present a pure case of squamous cell carcinoma with some areas of squamous metaplasia in the vicinity of the invasive tumor.

the three methods of assesing glycemic control , hba1c , smbg and cgms provide distinct information , yet complementary at the same time . hba1c does not equally reflect the glycemic values over the three months that forego its determination . 
 hba1c assesses the average glycemic exposure in time without being able to differentiate between preprandial and postprandial glycemia , possible hypo and hyper glycemia . 
 this method is able to identify both hypoglycemic and hyperglycemic episodes allowing immediate therapeutic decisions and therefore a glycemic balance closer to normal . 
 introduction of cgms in the assessment of the glycemic status represents a great technological advance . 
 this glucose monitoring method clears glycemic balance abnormalities in an otherwise impossible to ob
facts_entailed: There are three methods of assessing glycemic control: hba1c, SMBG, and CGMS.
hba1c assesses the average glycemic exposure in time without differentiating between preprandial and postprandial glycemia, possibly identifying hypo and hyperglycemia.
CGMS represents a great technological advance in glucose monitoring.
CGMS clears glycemic balance abnormalities that are otherwise impossible to observe.

 fear of hypoglycaemia and gain in body weight are barriers for initiation of insulin therapy .

A1CHIEVE is a multinational, 24-week, non-interventional study that assesses the safety and effectiveness of insulin analogues in people with t2 dm (n = 66,726) in routine clinical care.
The majority of patients (61.82%) started on or switched to biphasic insulin.

The predicted incidence of situs inversus totalis is one in 10,000 among the general population.
Situs inversus totalis is associated with syndromes such as Kartagener's syndrome and cardiac anomalies.

the importance of selenium for the life of animals has been known since the 1950s , while the essentiality of this element for humans was revealed in 1970s with the discovery of its ability to prevent the keshan disease , first described in 1935 in china in a province of the same name . 
 subsequently , it was discovered its important role as part of the body 's antioxidant mechanisms and also its role in protecting the body against heavy metals as well as its importance in the immune system [ 1 , 2 ] . 
 cow 's milk and dairy products are usually a poor source of selenium in human nutrition . 
 however , human milk is a poor source of selenium , so recently manufacturers of dairy - based infant formulas have added selenium to these products . 
 selenium has a very narrow range between die
facts_entailed: The importance of selenium for animals has been known since the 1950s.
The keshan disease was first described in China in 1935 in a province named Keshan.
It was later found that selenium plays important roles in the body's antioxidant mechanisms and in protecting against heavy metals and supporting the immune system.
Cow's milk and dairy products are typically poor sources of selenium in human nutrition.
Human milk is a poor source of selenium, leading to the addition of selenium to dairy-based infant formulas by manufacturers.
Selenium has a very narrow range between deficiency and toxicity.

Oseltamivir resistance testing was conducted using an enzyme inhibition assay (NA-Star; Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA) or by nucleotide sequencing of the NA gene to detect the H274Y mutation.
A 575-nt fragment of the NA gene and a 199-nt fragment of the M2 gene were amplified.

brugada syndrome ( brs ) is recognized as an important cause of sudden cardiac death ( scd ) occurring in individuals at a relatively young age . 
 brs is an inherited cardiac arrhythmia condition , characterized by coved st elevation and j point elevation of at least 2 mm in at least two of the right precordial electrocardiogram ( ecg ) leads ( v1 - 3)1 ) .

Protein fouling can damage biomedical devices, including coronary stents, ear grommets, and guide wires; it may also compromise the performance of biosensors, induce opsonization, and trigger clearance of nanocarriers from the bloodstream.

facts_entailed: Genome-wide genotype data was obtained from which 49 ancestry-matched, non-overlapping case-control samples were constructed.
46 of the case-control samples had European ancestry, and three had East Asian ancestry.
The case-control samples consisted of 34,241 cases and 45,604 controls.
Three family-based samples of European ancestry were also obtained (1,235 parent affected-offspring trios).
Genotypes from all studies were processed by the PGC using unified quality control procedures.
SNPs and insertions-deletions were imputed using the 1000 Genomes Project reference panel.
In each sample, association testing was conducted using imputed marker dosages and principal components (PCs) to control for population stratification.
After quality control, the imputation info score was set at 0.6, MAF at 0.01.

older adults are the chief users of emergency medical services ( ems ) , but we have paid little heed to understanding their special needs . 
 older patients use emergency services at higher rates , require more resources once in the emergency department ( ed ) and are more likely to experience adverse health outcomes compared with younger patients . a mechanism to identify those at higher risk for adverse outcomes may lead to improvements in care . 
 although older age groups use ems at disproportionately higher rates , paramedic training has changed little to meet the specific needs of this older demographic . 
 moreover , there has been very little alteration in how ems systems are organized , with agencies initially established to provide care for major trauma and cardiac arrest victim
facts_entailed: Older adults are the chief users of emergency medical services (EMS).
Older patients use emergency services at higher rates.
Older patients require more resources once in the emergency department (ED).
Older patients are more likely to experience adverse health outcomes compared with younger patients.
Although older age groups use EMS at disproportionately higher rates, paramedic training has changed little to meet the specific needs of this older demographic.
There has been very little alteration in how EMS systems are organized.
Agencies initially established to provide care for major trauma and cardiac arrest victims.

benign prostatic hyperplasia ( bph ) is one of the most common diseases in men of middle age and over in korea . 
 its importance and frequency are rapidly increasing as the result of increases in the elderly population , increases in the accessibility of westernized diets , increases in desires for improvements in quality of life , and other medical , social , and economical changes . 
 the early treatment chosen most often for bph is pharmacotherapy , but it is not appropriate for some patients . 
 when the side effects of pharmacotherapy , such as dry mouth and orthostatic hypotension , are severe , patients may choose surgical treatment instead . 
 also , in cases accompanied by repetitive urinary tract obstruction , infection , bladder stone , renal failure , and gross hematuria , sur
facts_entailed: Pharmacotherapy is not appropriate for some patients.
In cases accompanied by repetitive urinary tract obstruction, infection, bladder stone, renal failure, and gross hematuria, surgery may be necessary.

facts_entailed: An individual aged 44 years old, male, visited the hospital for back pain and a mass around the left buttock.
The patient had been taking medications from a local clinic and pharmacy for 1 month prior to the visit due to cold symptoms and lower back pain.
Vital signs upon visit included a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a body temperature of 38.3°C.
A painful mass was palpated on the left buttock area, appearing as reddish skin around the anterior superior iliac spine.
Laboratory investigations on admission showed a white blood cell count of 16,660/mm³ and a hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL.

facts_entailed: Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction is the most common form of upper urinary tract obstruction in children.
A study by Sampaio et al. found that an inferior accessory or aberrant artery crossed anteriorly to the UPJ in 6.8% of cases.
In some specimens, the inferior accessory artery passed close to the UPJ.

facts_entailed: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), including gefitinib and erlotinib, have considerably improved survival in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.
The dramatic efficacies of EGFR TKIs have been noted in selected subgroups, including women, never-smokers, those with histological adenocarcinoma, and those of Asian ethnicity.
Most tumors in these sensitive subgroups were related to EGFR sensitizing mutations.
These tumors responded better to EGFR TKIs than to conventional cytotoxic chemotherapies.
In several studies, TKIs are associated with a response rate according to response evaluation criteria in solid tumors of approximately 70% as well as a progression-free survival.

 a tight control of the tlr pathway is essential for maintaining homoeostasis , since overactivation of tlrs has been linked to various infectious and inflammatory diseases .

 the increase has been observed to be among women of all ages and race / ethnicities , in every state , and across all gestational ages . 
 many theories have been proffered to explain this trend , including a decrease in vaginal births after cesarean delivery ( vbac ) , decreased vaginal births of breech presentation , and increased prevalence of high risk pregnancies such as advanced maternal age and some subjective indications during labor such as nonreassuring fetal status and arrest of dilation [ 1 , 2 ] .

facts_entailed: Insults may cause neurodegeneration and impair the development of the CNS.
Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) is a growth factor belonging to the nerve growth factor (NGF) family of peptides.
BDNF has established effects on neuronal proliferation, regulation of neuronal function, and synaptic plasticity.
BDNF plays important roles in learning and memory.

facts_entailed: Local inflammatory response is observed in the early postoperative period.

the evolution of multi - cellular eukaryotic organisms from single - celled ancestors was one of the most significant transitions in the evolution of life on earth . 
 it enabled the emergence of larger and more complex eukaryotes that could resist predation , evolve specialized tissues and higher order biological capacities , and colonize new environments . 
 multi - cellularity evolved independently in several eukaryotic lineages and , in terms of the number of cell types per organism , animals ( the metazoa ) include the most complex multi - cellular eukaryotes ( rokas , 2008 ) . a key mediator of metazoan multi - cellularity is the extracellular matrix ( ecm ) , a multi - component , proteinaceous network that bridges between cells , contributes to their spatial arrangements by binding
facts_entailed: The evolution of multi-cellular eukaryotic organisms from single-celled ancestors was one of the most significant transitions in the evolution of life on Earth.

Multi-cellularity enabled the emergence of larger and more complex eukaryotes that could resist predation, evolve specialized tissues, and higher order biological capacities, and colonize new environments.
Multi-cellularity evolved independently in several eukaryotic lineages.
In terms of the number of cell types per organism, animals (the metazoa) include the most complex multi-cellular eukaryotes (Rokas, 2008).

A key mediator of metazoan multi-cellularity is the extracellular matrix (ECM), a multi-component, proteinaceous network that bridges between cells, contributes to their spatial arrangements by binding.

facts_entailed: Functional gastrointestinal disorder (FGID) is one of the most common digestive disease entities.
In recent years, a bio-psycho-social pathophysiological model has been implicated for the pathogenesis of FGID.
This model emphasizes the importance of biological, social, environmental, and psychological factors in the development of FGID.
The paper aims to review the epidemiology, mechanism, and psychological interventions of FGIDs.

facts_entailed: Stroke is characterized by a sudden, non-convulsive, focal neurological deficit caused by a brain lesion stemming from a non-traumatic vascular mechanism due to arterial or venous embolism leading to cerebral ischemia or hemorrhage.
The most common manifestations of stroke include sensory, cognitive, and motor impairments, such as hemiparesis, spasticity, an abnormal movement pattern, and physical deconditioning.

many fungi have yet to be collected and named , and it appears that the number of undescribed species is at least 1.4 million and probably as many as 3 million ( hawksworth 2012a ) . it is anticipated that many of these species are to be found in the tropics , and this poses particular constraints to their formal description . until the 1990s , tackling this task was generally by opportunist , short - stay visits to the tropics by european and north american mycologists ; something that can be likened to  smash - and - grab  raids . the material is often retained in the collector s institution though , where possible , some mycologists have split , and diligently repatriated , at least some of the specimens . as there were few centres anywhere in the tropics where fungal material could be
facts_entailed: Many fungi have yet to be collected and named.
It is estimated that the number of undescribed species is at least 1.4 million and possibly up to 3 million (Hawksworth 2012a).
It is anticipated that many of these species are found in the tropics.
This poses particular challenges to their formal description.
Until the 1990s, the task was generally tackled through opportunistic, short-stay visits to the tropics by European and North American mycologists.
These visits were akin to 'smash-and-grab' raids.
The material was often retained in the collector's institution.
Some mycologists have attempted to repatriate and carefully return at least some of the specimens.

The pharmaceutical industry is sponsoring a lot of research worldwide.
A significant portion of the pharmaceutical industry's budget is allocated to promotional activities.
Usual promotional activities include obliging doctors with minor gifts like stationery items, donating equipment, kits, and even sponsoring dinners and seminar participation.

facts_entailed: Pituitary adenomas (pas) are nonmetastasizing neoplasms consisting of adenohypophysial cells.
They usually occur in the sella-turcica but may occasionally be ectopic.
They are relatively common benign neoplasms with different clinical features.

According to the WHO classification in 2004, endocrine pituitary tumors are clinically classified as functioning (mainly secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone [ACTH] with cushing's disease; growth hormone [GH] with acromegaly and prolactin [PRL] with amenorrhea galactorrhea) and nonfunctioning (mainly LH and follicle-stimulating hormone [FSH]).

facts_entailed: The study was approved by the Danish Data Protection Agency (2007-58-0015).
Local register-based studies in which persons can not be identified do not require ethics approval in Denmark.
All Danish citizens are medically covered by a tax-financed system providing free health care.
All hospitalizations (in-hospital and outpatient visits) since 1978 have been recorded in the Danish National Patient Registry.
All prescription claims from Danish pharmacies since 1995 have been recorded in the Danish Register of Medicinal Product Statistics.
Registration of all births and deaths, including dates of occurrence, has been complete for all citizens since 1968.

facts_entailed: Many adolescents often lack strong and stable relationships with their parents or other adults.
These relationships are necessary for openly discussing reproductive health concerns.
In most cultures, parents and family members are an influential source of knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and values for children and young people.
Parents often have the power to guide children's development in sexual health matters.
Encouraging reasonable sexual behavior and good personal decision-making skills is common when parents are involved.
Research indicated that increased parent-child communication leads to higher awareness and reduced risk-taking behaviors.
However, young people may feel disconnected when these relationships are lacking.
